Your Brain on Klimt:
 Our brains assemble Gustav Klimt’s paintings piece by piece, symbol by

3146889011.resolved_title: From fluffy to valuable: How the brain recognises objects
3146889011.excerpt: To recognise a chair or a dog, our brain separates objects into their individual properties and then puts them back together. Until recently, it has remained unclear what these properties are.

1.caption:
The human brain breaks down the environment into a total of 49 properties, which are sufficient to categorise all objects. Depending on how similar the observed object is to a known category, it is then recognised as a dog or, for instance, a piece of furniture.

© shutterstock

FlyEM/Janelia Research Campus

4.caption: A big brown bat’s ability to echolocate allows it to thrive in the dark.

8.caption: Manatee whiskers can detect currents in the water, but not quickly enough to dodge loud, fast boats.

3237663910.excerpt: The concept: When we look at a chair, regardless of its shape and color, we know that we can sit on it. When a fish is in water, regardless of its location, it knows that it can swim. This is known as the theory of affordance, a term coined by psychologist James J. Gibson.

The vehicle will take you there, but it isn’t you.

1.caption: A study of "harmonic surprise"—points where the music deviates from listener expectations—in popular music over several decades found that Childish Gambino's "This Is America" had the most contrastive harmonic surprise.

3902850886.resolved_title: How Psychedelics Can Heal a Broken Mind

3766082188.given_title: How the Brain Distinguishes Memories From Perceptions
3766082188.resolved_title: How the Brain Distinguishes Memories From Perceptions
3766082188.excerpt: The neural representations of a perceived image and the memory of it are almost the same. New work shows how and why they are different.

1.caption:
Perception and memory use some of the same areas of the brain. Small but significant differences in the neural representations of memories and perceptions may enable us to distinguish which one we are experiencing at any moment.


Kristina Armitage/Quanta Magazine

2454106010.resolved_title: The Brain Maps Out Ideas and Memories Like Spaces
2454106010.excerpt: Emerging evidence suggests that the brain encodes abstract knowledge in the same way that it represents positions in space, which hints at a more universal theory of cognition.

1.caption:
In the parable of the blind men and the elephant, each paid attention to a different aspect of the creature. The brain may do something similar by mapping out the qualities of perceptions, experiences and abstract concepts along various dimensions, with the help of the same system that it uses to map out physical spaces.


Alexandre Tamisier for Quanta Magazine

4004274842.resolved_title: Shari Liu: How babies think about danger

3667466162.resolved_title: The mysterious inner life of the octopus

1.caption: The octopus has a body plan and nervous system very unlike our own – yet we share the capacity to experience pain, and possibly other feelings

2.caption: Octopuses are talented escape artists, known to unscrew jars from the inside and open the lids of their containers

3.caption: Understanding octopus sentience could help improve their welfare in captivity, and feed into debates on the ethics of farming them

4.caption: We still don't know exactly why consciousness evolved, but it could be closely tied up with complex behaviours and learning to deal with novel situations

2049322555.given_title: What to Do When Your Brain Insists You’re Always on a Boat - Facts So Roman
2049322555.resolved_title: What to Do When Your Brain Insists You’re Always on a Boat
2049322555.excerpt: A few years ago, Chris Perry went on an Alaskan cruise with her family to celebrate her parents’ 50th wedding anniversary.

1.caption: Chris Perry had felt the world bobbing beneath her feet for nearly four months, suffering from a disorder rather poetically dubbed Mal de Debarquement syndrome.

2.caption: Chris Perry undergoing treatment in Mingjia Dai’s lab at Mount Sinai Hospital. Left: Perry stands on a Wii Balance Board. Center: An acclerometer measures her perceived swaying. Right: Rotating vertical stripes are used to reset the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

3790067331.given_title: Where does your sense of self come from? A scientific look | Anil Ananthasw
3790067331.resolved_title: Anil Ananthaswamy: Where does your sense of self come from? A scientific look
3790067331.excerpt: Our memories and bodies give us clues about who we are, but what happens when this guidance shifts? In this mind-bending talk, science writer Anil Ananthaswamy shares how the experiences of "altered selves" -- resulting from schizophrenia, Alzheimer's, foreign limb syndrome or other conditions -- shed light on the constructed nature of identity. He breaks down where our sense of self comes from and invites us to challenge our assumptions about who we are, with the aim of building a better you and a better world.

3999255225.excerpt: Flickering dots and smudges of light everywhere, fuzz and static blanketing my visual field, blurring the edges of my reality. For as long as I can remember, this is what I have seen when I look out onto the world.

3363896388.given_title: Why it took us thousands of years to see the colour violet | Psyche Ideas
3363896388.resolved_title: Why it took us thousands of years to see the colour violet
3363896388.excerpt: As a schoolboy in Soviet Russia in the 1960s, my hands were almost never clean. Don’t get me wrong – I washed them as much as anyone else. But the school rules made us practise our penmanship in ink, which came in violet.

3048461012.given_title: Why line-dried laundry smells so good
3048461012.resolved_title: Why line-dried laundry smells so good
3048461012.excerpt: An unusual experiment clarifies why laundry that dries outdoors smells so good. The findings, published in Environmental Chemistry, show that towels that dried in the sun produced a range of aldehydes and ketones: organic compounds that our noses associate with the scent of plants or perfume.

1.caption: For example, line-dried towels emitted pentanal, a compound found in cardamom; octanal, which emits citrus-like aromas; and nonanal, which has a rose-like odor.

2745859610.given_title: Why Red Means Red in Almost Every Language - Issue 76: Language
2745859610.resolved_title: Why Red Means Red in Almost Every Language
2745859610.excerpt: The confounding consistency of color categories. When Paul Kay, then an anthropology graduate student at Harvard University, arrived in Tahiti in 1959 to study island life, he expected to have a hard time learning the local words for colors.

2.caption: Gilbert, A.L., Reiger, T., Kay, P., & Ivry, R.B. Whorf hypothesis is supported in the right visual field but not the left. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 103, 489–494

3.caption: BABY BLUES: In laboratory tests, psychologists have found that babies tend to stare longer at colors that from categories they haven’t seen before, suggesting that our ability to perceive boundaries between colors may exist as early as infancy.

3830044158.given_title: Why the dyslexic brain is misunderstood
3830044158.resolved_title: Why the dyslexic brain is misunderstood
3830044158.excerpt: Dyslexia is a differently organized brain. The brain isn’t naturally wired to read. It’s a task that requires explicit instruction for our brains to activate different areas, including those that control vision, sound, and meaning.

3875834028.given_title: Why we sometimes sense invisible others
3875834028.resolved_title: 'Felt presence': Why we sometimes feel invisible others
3875834028.excerpt: It was 2015 and Luke Robertson was skiing across Antarctica alone. There was nothing to see but vast expanses of snow and ice. Two weeks into a planned 40-day unsupported journey to the South Pole, he was behind schedule, feeling exhausted and demoralised.

1.caption: As Luke Robertson slogged further into his solo South Pole trek, he had more episodes of "felt presence"

2.caption: The feeling of a mysterious presence is sometimes associated with those who've had a bereavement, suffered psychosis or have diseases such as Parkinson's

3.caption: Robertson's brain might have been creating the "company" he needed to complete his arduous trek

3738460144.given_title: Why Your Brain Isn't Into the Future - Nautilus
3738460144.resolved_title: Why Your Brain Isn’t Into the Future
3738460144.excerpt: Living for the moment gets a bad rap. If you’re smart, people say, you should work toward a good future, sacrificing fun and pleasure in the present. Yet there are good reasons to discount the future, which is why economists tend to do it when making predictions.
